summary: This document appears to be a series of text messages or chat logs from August 29, 2019, discussing Jeffrey Epstein's alleged connections to Cuba, referencing a trip with Glenn and Craig, and linking to an article titled 'Epstein's Castro Odyssey' by Humberto Fontova. The article explores Epstein's travel to Cuba, the environment of child prostitution there, and potential blackmail by Castro's regime.

persons.name: Danny
persons.context: Mentioned in a text message as someone from Miami who knows Epstein and said he procured girls in Cuba for Glenn and Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central subject of the document; his travel to Cuba, potential blackmail by Castro's regime, and his suicide in jail are discussed.

persons.name: Glenn
persons.context: Referenced in text messages as having taken a trip to Cuba with Craig, and for whom Epstein allegedly procured girls.

persons.name: Craig
persons.context: Mentioned as accompanying Glenn on a trip to Cuba and making a book for Glenn that was kept on his yacht.

persons.name: Fidel Castro
persons.context: Described as having invited Epstein to Cuba; his regime's intelligence operations and potential blackmail of visitors are discussed.

persons.name: Andres Pastrana
persons.context: Quoted as stating that Epstein traveled to Cuba at Castro's invitation in March 2003.

persons.name: Julia O'Connell Davidson
persons.context: Cited for her study on prostitution in Cuba, noting the vulnerability of young girls.

persons.name: Delfin Fernandez
persons.context: Quoted describing how Castro's intelligence bugged hotel rooms and followed American visitors in Cuba.

persons.name: Andrew Lindy
persons.context: Creator of 'The Cuba Prostitution Documentary' which documented rampant prostitution in Cuba in 2011.

persons.name: Amado Fahkre
persons.role: Millionaire investor, business associate of Epstein
persons.context: Named as a rich and famous friend of Epstein who invested heavily in Cuba and was later imprisoned and robbed by the Castro regime.

persons.name: Stephen Purvis
persons.context: British business partner of Fahkre who was also imprisoned in Cuba on corruption charges.

persons.name: Humberto Fontova
persons.context: Author of the 'Epstein's Castro Odyssey' article linked and discussed in the text messages.

connections.description: Epstein allegedly procured girls in Cuba for Glenn, according to a message from Danny.
Glenn took a trip to Cuba with Craig several years ago, as recalled in a text message.
Epstein traveled to Cuba at Castro's invitation in March 2003, according to former Colombian President Andres Pastrana.
Fahkre is listed as a rich and famous friend in Epstein's 'Little Black Book' and also had business dealings in Cuba.
Business partners who invested heavily in Cuba and were both imprisoned by the Castro regime.

events.title: Epstein's trip to Cuba
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein traveled to Havana, Cuba, reportedly at the invitation of President Fidel Castro.

events.title: Andrew Lindy's documentary filming
events.description: Canadian filmmaker Andrew Lindy visited Cuba and documented rampant prostitution, finding many women and girls offering sex for pay.

events.title: Arrest of Amado Fahkre and Stephen Purvis
events.description: Businessmen Amado Fahkre and Stephen Purvis were arrested in Cuba, robbed of their assets, and imprisoned for two years on corruption charges.

events.title: Epstein's death in jail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide in his jail cell, as noted in the article.

keyFacts: A text message claims 'Danny from Miami' said Epstein procured girls in Cuba for Glenn and Epstein.
An article by Humberto Fontova cites former Colombian President Andres Pastrana stating Epstein traveled to Cuba at Fidel Castro's invitation in March 2003.
The article describes Cuba under Castro as a hub for child prostitution, with quotes from studies noting the vulnerability of girls as young as 14-15.
Epstein expressed concern about spurious allegations and blackmail in a 2003 interview, as referenced in the article.
Epstein's associate Amado Fahkre and his partner Stephen Purvis were imprisoned and robbed by the Castro regime after investing heavily in Cuban golf courses and hotels.
